questions.question_text: When an Expressway-E is configured for static NAT, which Session Description Protocol attribute is modified to reflect the NAT address?

discussion.content: C is correct as c-line shows the connection information, Media IP address. So if it is natted it will be reflected there.

Selected Answer: C
With static NAT enabled on LAN2 of the Expressway-E, the c-line of the SIP INVITE has now been rewritten to c=IN IP4 64.100.0.10, and this means that when endpoint B sends outbound RTP media to endpoint A, this will be sent to IP address 64.100.0.10, the public NAT address of the NAT router, which is 1:1 NATed to the LAN2 IP address of the Expressway-E, 10.0.10.2. As RTP media from endpoint B arrives at the NAT router with a destination IP address of 64.100.0.10, the NAT router will forward these packets to the Expressway-E at 10.0.10.2 and two-way media is achieved.

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/expressway/config_guide/X8-5/Cisco-Expressway-Basic-Configuration-Deployment-Guide-X8-5-2.pdf
it should be D

comments.content: No it shouldn't. B is correct.

discussion.content: The possible modes are "local CPL, policy service, or off"
B. local CPL, policy service, and off

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
The Call Policy mode controls from where the Expressway obtains its Call Policy configuration. The options are:
■ Local CPL: uses locally-defined Call Policy.
■ Policy service: uses an external policy service.
■ Off: Call Policy is not in use.

Selected Answer: B
should be B

Selected Answer: B

The correct answer should be "local CPL" or "policy service" with the wording of the question. That isn't an option. I would not say "on" as that isn't a call policy mode.

discussion.content:
Everyone on here is wrong.. Let's read the question again, words are important on a cisco exam. "Which mode should be used when Call Policy is configured on Expressways?" not which modes are available, but which one should be used when it's configured on the expressway. questions.question_text: Which mode should be used when Call Policy is configured on Expressways?

choices.B: local CPL, policy service, and off

questions.question_text: When designing the call control on a Cisco Expressway Core, which is the sequence of dial plan functions?

discussion.content: A. transforms, CPL, user policy, search rules

Selected Answer: A
he pre-search transform function allows you to modify the alias in an incoming search request. The transformation is applied by the Expressway before any Call Policy (CPL) or User Policy is applied, and before any searches take place.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/expressway/admin_guide/X14-0/exwy_b_cisco-expressway-administrator-guide/exwy_m_dial-plan-and-call-processing.html#reference_18DBC558E34532EB78E9603EF988C3AB
Should be A

Selected Answer: A
Proof in the comments below.

A is the Answer...
https://ccieme.wordpress.com/2016/11/07/14-4-cisco-vcs-dial-plan-components/

A is correct.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XGV29NxHoVk
Correct answer is A
The right order is transforms, then CPL, and lastly Search Rules.

questions.question_text: Which two items are configured when deploying a B2B collaboration solution? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A and B
A & B are correct

A & B 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/unified-communications/expressway/213864-configure-business-to-business-audio-and.html
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/unified-communications/expressway/213864-configure-business-to-business-audio-and.html#anc14

Transversal Client is only expressway C.
The good answers are AB

comments.content: On Expressway-E you would need in that case a traversal server, not a client.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
But what if there is no CUCM in the mix? You might have endpoints directly registered to the C, or to a TMS. You'd definately need search rules (B), but a B2B also requires a traversal zone, which means you'd need a traversal client on the E (answer D). And you'd have to have this even if you were using a CUCM (or not). So I think the answers here are B and D

choices.A: Configure the Expressway-E by using a non-traversal server zone.
choices.B: Enable static NAT on the Expressway-E only.
choices.D: Enable H.323 H.460.19 demultiplexing mode on the Expressway-C.
choices.C: Disable H.323 mode on the Expressway-E.

questions.question_text: Which step is taken when configuring a Cisco Expressway solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The Expressway-E has both NICs enabled, and static NAT enabled on its outward-facing LAN interface. The Expressway-C inside the network is a traversal client of the Expressway-E in the DMZ.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/expressway/config_guide/X14-0/basic_config/exwy_b_cisco-expressway-e-and-expressway-c-basic-configuration-deployment-guide-x14-0/exwy_m_advanced-networking-deployments.html
B - Expressway E is to be natted only
